Related to issue #847
Fixes broken list documentation in SC.DateTime:unknownProperty and makes the formatter characters monospaced so that they are easier to read (%j and %I were hard to read).
Fixes documentation problem with strange quoting.

Attempts to improve the documentation for %E formatter.  Removes mention of %e as a format parameter, because it is confusing.  Instead adds the full list of localized strings to the documentation (in case the person is working off the gem and doesn't have access to the SproutCore source) and also makes a note about %e's usage in the context of those localized strings.

Also slightly improves the documentation for `difference` method and cleans whitespace.
The result should be rounded

Throw errors is the passed parameters are invalid

As suggest by dcporter an error is now throw for the methods: compare,
compareDate and difference if the parameters are incorrect.
We should probably start commenting better.
Improved String.fmt handling of missing named arguments.
String formatter - Added failing unit test for missing-named-argument feature.

The SC.Store.reset() method was not clearing out previously constructed
RecordArrays, even though the underlying data hash was being cleared.
While technically this is valid -> most of the storekeys are set to
SC.Record.EMPTY rather than being deleted altogether, which means the
storeKey lists inside of the RA's aren't invalidated -> it seems a
little strange that a method labeled "reset" does not, in fact, clean up
the entire store.

This patch ensures that the entire store is cleared, and adds a few unit
tests that enforce the one-record-array-per-query contract.
delete emptyView in template_collection after removing from tree
Fixes exception when trying to remove the SC.platform test style if the stylesheet being inspected doesn't have cssRules.

Fixes regression with layout styles where switching from centered to non-centered layouts would fail to remove the margin styles.

Includes unit test.

Fixes the order of the container and segmented view in the DOM for SC.TabView so that the segmented view should be rendered above the container without having to resort to forced z-index settings.

Includes unit test.
Bumps the showcase submodule to the latest.
Fixes a problem with destroying SC.ContainerViews leftover after the API for transitions was changed to share one transition plugin between all the content.  Also updates the statechart diagram.
Cleans up SC.CollectionView a la jshint.  Also removes a number of declared, initialized yet unused variables.

Fixes a regression with SC.CollectionView that occurred after a previous fix to remove a view DOM leak.  SC.CollectionView previously created a view with the same layerId as the view to be replaced before replacing it, which only worked because of some weird logic external to the CollectionView that used to prevent a view from being able to find its layer if it didn't have a parentView (which was also the cause of a leak because the layer might still exist in the DOM).  In any case, having two views use the same layerId at the same time is a bad idea.

So instead we essentially use removeChild().insertBefore() rather than insertBefore().removeChild() (i.e. replaceChild()).
Adds a developer error message if an SC.View is created using an existing layerId.  This should prevent some weirdness from occurring.
Fixes placement of Developer Warning and updates the test to remove improper use.
Provides backwards compatibility for providing the callback inside of the options object and adds warnings that only the standard arguments should be used.  Fixes #861 for 1.10.

Fixes some documentation for proper jsDoc usage.  Renames the SC.ANIMATION_POSITION enum to SC.LayoutState, which follows the JavaScript style guideline for enums and better illustrates that it is a state not necessarily a position (i.e. animating opacity doesn't effect position).

Changes the internal classNames of SC.Theme to be an Array rather than a CoreSet.  Having it as a Set makes no sense and the amount of property overloading is ridiculous.  We have to check for Objects, Arrays, Strings and Sets, which is a waste of code rather than just standardizing on an Array like classNames is on SC.View.  Also, this causes problems if developers use the theme's classNames and assume it will be an Array like with SC.View.

This is a potentially incompatible change, but it actually fixes current code that uses the theme's classNames with the updated SC.RenderContext API so it should potentially work with any current code.  Also, because this API is so under-used, hopefully it will not affect any implementations.  Though, if it does cause actual backwards incompatibility, it will have to be reverted for 1.10.
Improves the PUSH animation to be more fluid (avoid cancelling the entering and exiting animations) and fixes a regression where the initially set nowShowing would transition on when it shouldn't.

Changes SC.ANIMATION_POSITION API.final to 'end' because final prevents minification.  Changes SC.ANIMATION_POSITION.original to 'start' to better reflect the outcome with respect to 'end' and 'current'.  Adds missing animation unit test for cancelAnimation with SC.ANIMATION_POSITION.start without transforms.
Updates transition support tests for refactored code.

Forces the transition to be the same for all content statecharts.  This prevents multiple transition plugins from occurring in the content statecharts, which would be messy to manage and less performant.  If a view should have a different exit transition from its entrance transition, the proper transition plugin should be created and assigned.  This fixes a bug where setting the transition later doesn't update the current content view to use it.

Completely refactors the transition implementation for SC.ContainerView in order to properly support multiple nowShowing changes with transition animations.

After struggling to make the container view handle multiple nowShowing changes while the previous items were still exiting, I had to step back and draw up the proper statechart for the container view to try and figure out why I couldn't get certain transitions to behave exactly as they should.  I determined that the container view's states are very basic, but what was missing was that each content view needed its own statechart in order to manage its own state.  For instance, a content view may be told to exit multiple times while it is in the process of exiting and the number of times it is told to exit may effect its transition.  Therefore, I added a simple statechart, SC.ContainerContentStatechart, that the container view can create for each new content and give control of the content's transitioning to.  This makes it possible to do very complex transitions, such as the PUSH transition that adjusts its exit animation accordingly to account for being pushed off before even being fully pushed on.
Adds SC.ContainerView statechart diagram.
Tidies code.
Updates SC.ContainerView to work with updated animate method which doesn't require manually calling invokeLater.
Uses the new liveAdjustments property to get the current position of the view even if it is being transformed for the transition.

Fixes SC.ContainerView transitioning on awake with current nowShowing value.  Improves each transition to allow for multiple transitions to be called before each is completed.  Fixes the value of 'isTransitioning' while multiple transitions are in effect.  Makes all methods except 'run' of SC.TransitionProtocol optional.
Adds unit tests for transition plugin support in SC.ContainerView.
Makes it possible to use an SC.View instance or class as the original nowShowing value of SC.ContainerView.
Fixes transitions addition to SC.ContainerView.

Implements first version of transition plugin support for SC.ContainerView.  Instead of simply swapping views, SC.ContainerView can now be given a transition plugin that it will use to animate the swap.  This commit includes a few useful transition plugins PUSH, DISSOLVE, MOVE_IN, REVEAL and FADE_COLOR and a protocol, SC.TranstionProtocol, that a developer can use to build custom transitions.

Fixes problem with previous invokeNext() change.  If a run loop timer is fired in the current run loop and therefore unschedule's itself, it didn't reset the internal _timeoutAt variable which meant that attempting to schedule a new run loop timer would not work.

Includes unit test.

Fixes problems with SC.View's animate() refactor.  First, the original layout hash was being altered for animation before being cloned when it should have been cloned first.  This mean that if the view had not yet been rendered, it would have been rendered with the altered animate layout the first time.  Second, willRenderAnimations could be called before the animation layout was applied if the view had not yet been rendered, which would result in the animation styles being applied too early.
Removes developer warnings in SC.browser from non-debug builds.
Updates and corrects tests to work with refactored layout style code.

Further refactors animation and the calculation of layout styles by replacing the LayoutStyleCalculator instance with a single LayoutStyleCalculator object.  Previously, each SC.View created an SC.LayoutStyleCalculator object that it used in a truly dubious manner.  The LayoutStyleCalculator was supposed to be a group of functions that could be shared between all views, but instead each view had to create and modify its own instance of the calculator.  The calculator had several internal state variables which meant it could not be shared between views.  The calculator also cross-referenced the view itself and was never cleaned up resulting in a memory leak.

This update untangles the view from the calculator so that the calculator can be shared between views (not really much reason to even have this separate, but none-the-less…) and fixes the memory leak of SC.LayoutStyleCalculator instances.
Extends the cleanup callback for the platform event tests.  This helps to ensure that the event comes in even if the browser is busy, before the fallback clean up occurs.

Refactors SC.View:animate().

- animate() uses invokeNext() so that the developer never needs to monkey with the run loop in order to call animate().  Animations will only begin after the browser has had a chance to flush any changes to the DOM, thus ensuring that the animation actually occurs.  This will make using .animate() much easier whereas previously, developers would revert to invokeLaters to try and make sure the DOM style existed before animate would adjust it.
- the animate() function can now accept a target argument as well as a method, which conforms to the standard used by many methods in SproutCore.
- if no target it given the view itself will be the value of `this` in the callback.  Previously, this would be the layoutStyleCalculator, an internal object of SC.View.
- the animate() function is thoroughly documented now, including notes on how to hardware accelerate position changes.
- uses new additions to SC.platform and SC.browser to make animations forward compatible and fixes animate() on Firefox nightly
- hardware accelerated styles no longer remain in the DOM after the animation completes (i.e. sometimes the translate values would stay in the style)
- resetAnimation() has been renamed to cancelAnimation(), because reset indicates 'revert', but the default behavior doesn't revert the layout.
- added SC.ANIMATION_POSITION constant for use by cancelAnimation().
- fixes hasAcceleratedLayer to be dependent on the layout.  Previously, adjusting a non-accelerated layout to an accelerate-able layout failed to update the property and hasAcceleratedLayer would be incorrect.
- cancelAnimation() can now cancel an animation and adjust the layout to its current value during the transition, to its original value or to the final value which is the default.
- adds a private `liveAdjustments` property to SC.View, which will return the current value of properties that are being animated.  This even works for accelerated transitions that use transforms and return CSSMatrix values while animating.
- simplifies the code somewhat and cleans up a lot of loose ends that remained since the original code was largely copy-pasted over from the old animation framework.
- removes an observer on the view's layout from within the layoutStyleCalculator and properly chained up the dependencies to remove some manual notification code.
- includes new unit tests
Updates test to use proper domPrefix value rather than the deprecated version.

Refactors transition and animation testing of SC.platform; adds SC.browser.cssPrefix, SC.browser.domPrefix and SC.browser.classPrefix; adds SC.browser. experimentalNameFor(), SC.browser. experimentalStyleNameFor() and SC.browser. experimentalCSSNameFor() methods; and adds SC.UNSUPPORTED constant.

There were many problems with the animation and transition tests that existed before.  There was no forward support so browsers, like the Firefox nightly that have dropped prefixes, would fail to identify as supporting transitions and transforms.  Also, animation event listeners were hard coded into RootResponder for webkit only.  Also the event names needed to be forward supported as well and because there is no consistency in the event naming, the real transition and animation events may not have been captured on certain browsers.

Now, SC.platform does quick and precise tests to determine the actual event names allowing the RootResponder to listen only to the properly named events rather than using a shotgun approach with a bunch of different browser prefixes.

To make the code forward compatible for when prefixes are dropped, SC.browser has three new support functions:  experimentalNameFor(), experimentalStyleNameFor(), experimentalCSSNameFor().  These functions return the proper name for experimental names for object classes & properties, DOM properties and CSS attributes, not by guessing, but by testing the standard name and then testing prefixed versions of the name if necessary.  This allows developers to avoid writing code like:  SC.browser.cssPrefix + "box-shadow black 0 1px 2px", which will fail on browsers that no longer need a prefix and instead use:  SC.browser.experimentalCSSNameFor('boxShadow'), which will return either "box-shadow", some browser prefix + "box-shadow" or SC.UNSUPPORTED (allowing you to do something else).

- The css prefix and dom prefix were calculated from the user agent, which duplicated work already done with more rigor in SC.browser.
- Fixes duplicate 'input' property in SC.platform.
- Deprecates SC.platform.cssPrefix and SC.platform.domCSSPrefix.
Cleans whitespace.
Cleans whitespace.

Makes the rendering of animation layouts asynchronous always to ensure that the current layout of the View gets rendered to the DOM.  If the current layout is not rendered, the animation layout will be all the DOM sees and thus it won't trigger an animation change.   This should make using SC.View:animate much easier, especially for new developers.

Also scrubs layout_style.js to remove a number of unused variables, support the above change and optimize the variable declarations.  This optimization dropped the minified file size from 9,322 bytes down to 8,914 bytes (408 bytes reduced).
Improves the documentation for invokeNext.
Fixes CoreTest.Runner to start on the updated jQuery ready event.

Makes invokeNext trigger the next run of the run loop if none is scheduled.   This makes invokeNext the appropriate method to use when needing the DOM to be up-to-date before running code against it.

Previously, invokeNext functions would not run until the next run loop occurred, which if there were no events or timers, might mean that the code won't run for a long time.  While invokeLast lets you put code at the end of the run loop, the DOM will not have yet been updated and invokeLater is risky to use at small intervals, because if the interval is too small, the invokeLater code will run in the current run of the run loop and again the DOM will not have been updated.  Instead, invokeNext now ensures that the run loop completes execution and schedules an immediate timeout in order to allow the browser to update the DOM.

This works with the timer additions to the run loop, so additional run loops only run once even if there is an invokeLater expiring at the same time as the invokeNext timeout triggers a new run loop.

- Includes unit test.
- Fixes bug in previous unit test that left a run loop unfinished.
Fixes improper use of execUnsafeLocalFunction polyfill so that jQuery tests work properly.
Fixes typo of missing '@' on endif, which would cause non-debug builds to become invalid.
Updates all render context methods to use the updated API.  This should make it clearer that the context is not a jQuery object and shouldn't be used like one.

Fixes bug noticed by updated jQuery.  The previous version of SC.RenderContext:addStyle() would replace styles, which was really only due to an undocumented behavior of jQuery, plus it is semantically incorrect for 'add' to replace.  The refactor of RenderContext makes the functions behave properly.

Refactors SC.RenderContext to simplify the API, introduce consistent naming and make it behave appropriately.  This should remove the guess work about whether a function is or is not supported by the context and make it easier to remember the names and parameters of each method.

- There are now 3 similar access methods:  attrs(), classes(), styles()
- There are now 3 similar add methods:  addAttr(), addClass(), addStyle()
- There are now 3 similar remove methods: removeAttr(), removeClass(), removeStyle()
- There are now 2 similar reset methods: resetClasses(), resetStyles()
- Fully backwards compatible.
- Duplicate and inconsistent method names have been deprecated:  css(), html(), classNames(), resetClassNames(), attr()
- Adds several Developer Warnings to aid developers in updating their code (in debug mode only as not to take up space in production).
- Removes some code duplication and simplifies the code.
Adds a failing unit test to show a problem caused by the update of jQuery which introduced a bug where the previous layout style will be amended rather than overwritten.

Added platform detection for the Apache Cordova (formerly phonegap)
javascript-to-mobile bridge. Also added gitignore entries for .project
and .settings, which are eclipse-specific configuration files.

Changes the patch of jQuery to use execUnsafeLocalFunction, which doesn't alter the test HTML used by jQuery and therefore should not effect the outcome of the jQuery tests while still removing the annoying IE warnings.

Patches jQuery to prevent security exceptions in IE.

This does NOT patch jQuery to make all calls to .append(), .insert(), etc. pass security validation in IE.  Instead it uses toStaticHTML (as recommended by Microsoft) to strip 3 innerHTML strings used within jQuery for testing.
Gets rid of deprecated code and warning on IE.

Updates jQuery framework to 1.8.3 and removes buffered jQuery.

Buffered jQuery theoretically improves performance by grouping all DOM manipulations through jQuery into a queue that can be flushed at once, but this needs to be benchmarked to be properly understood.

• Improves animation support for current and future browsers.  The previous platform checks prevented using accelerated layers on non-webkit platforms, plus any browser that dropped the prefixes would indicate that they did not have support for transitions and transforms.

- May effect issue #867

Fixes a bug that left childView elements in the DOM when they were rendered as part of their parent's layer and later removed.

If childView layers are rendered when the parentView's  layer is created, the `layer` property on the childView will not be cached.  What occurs is that if the childView is then removed from the parent view without ever having its `layer` requested, when it comes time to destroy the DOM layer of the childView, it will try to find it with a `get('layer')`.  The bug was that it only returned a layer if the view has a parent view.  However, since the child was removed from the parent first and then destroyed, it no longer has a parent view and would not try to find its leftover DOM layer.

- Includes unit test.
Cleans whitespace + updates jslint
Fixes SC.View:resetAnimation() to be closer to functioning, but more research needs to be done on this.  It previously did not work at all.
Removes :template_view as default framework.
Updates CHANGELOG.md.

Fixes improper implementation of SC.SelectionSet:constrain (fixes #870).

After cleaning up a memory leak in SC.Set, it was discovered that the constrain method of SC.SelectionSet doesn't work properly.  It was naively using forEach to iterate through the objects while mutating the array so that the last object would never be constrained.  Includes unit test.

Fixes problem with cleaning up bindings on SC.View.  Previously, SC.View would destroy itself first before calling the super destroy method.  This would remove the parentView object from all childViews, which meant that when the super destroy method tried to remove bindings and observers, it was unable to resolve any parentView property paths.

With this change, we call the super method first to destroy bindings and observers and then clear out the parentView of each view.
Adds unit test showing that relative bindings to parentView in SC.View instances are not being cleaned up properly.

Merge pull request #864 from mitchless/menu-memory-leak

Fix implicitly defined globals in SC.MenuPane
Implicit globals, creating a possible memory leak. Not sure if these were in fact cause a problem but as I was looking to extend this class those jumped out at me.

Extends SC.Observable:destroyObservable to also remove observers.

- Previously the object would remain registered in other object's ObserverSets and could not be freed.
- Adds tests for destroyObservable behavior.
Removes excess whitespace.

Fixes memory leak in SC.Set.

The way that SC.Set removes objects is to "untrack" the internal index of the object by shrinking its length, but it never actually removed the object at the last index.  The only way that the object could be freed is if a new object is inserted at the same internal index, thus replacing it.  If the objects were removed in the reverse order that they were added, every object would still be in the set (until they were possibly overwritten).

Merge pull request #858 from ricolicious/fix-string.fmt-docs

Fixes example code in SC.String.fmt

Fixes the excess calling of parentViewDidResize on child views when the view's position changes, but it's size doesn't. Previously, views that had fixed sizes (i.e. width + height), but not fixed positions (i.e. not left + top) would still call parentViewDidResize on their own child views each time that the view's parent view resized.  However, this isn't necessary, because changes to the view's parent view will effect the view's frame, but if the view has a fixed size, it will not effect the child view's frames.

- This fixes a strange issue that occurs with SC.ImageView's viewDidResize implementation, where it fails to resize appropriately.
- This separates isFixedLayout into isFixedPosition + isFixedSize, allowing us more options to decide what to do when the layout is a fixed position vs. a fixed size vs. both vs. neither.
- Note: A similar optimization already exists in layoutDidChange.
Adds unit tests that show that parent view resizes are cascading needlessly to child views.  Fixed in next commit.
Removes extra whitespace.
Updates the Changelog.

Adds SC.appCache and SC.platform.supportsApplicationCache.

Working with the application cache is a confusing and time-consuming task.  This simple object abstracts out the most important properties for developers to use: hasNewVersion, isNewVersionValid, progress and isReadyForOffline all the while using the minimum number of event listeners which are properly cleaned up when unneeded.  It also has a property shouldPoll that will lazily look for updates in the background at a fixed interval.  This could be especially useful in a test environment, where you want to ensure that the testers aren't running the old version (which happens frequently when using the application cache).

Fixes SC.Object.prototype.mixin so that the mixed in objects' observables are initialized.

- Instead of using SC.mixin (suitable for mixing into a Class), we use SC._object_extend on the object itself with the mixins.  This registers the _bindings, _properties and _observers set up variables for initObservable.
- We then reset the initObservable() status and run it again using our new  _bindings, _properties and _observers to be setup.

Removes unneeded Arrays from SC.Object classes.

- Once initObservable is called we don't need the set up properties any longer, so we can remove them to save memory.

Fixes critical bug in animation where animating a layout property and then later animating a different layout property on the same view would throw an exception.  This is because when the animation ended event fired the code would delete the matching layout property from the _activeAnimations placeholder variable completely, but later code that was supposed to clear out any other animations that were part of that same group, would end up setting the layout property from undefined to null.  This was bad, because the _activeAnimations object is iterated using for..in and so we don't want the key to exist.

Instead, when the animation ends, we delete all animations in the group instead of setting them to null.

Fixes #230.  When reopening a class, we have to also re-configure all current subclasses of that class.  If we don't, then any computed properties, bindings or observers added in the reopen() won't be registered in instances of the subclass.

Fixes createNestedRecord for child records without primary keys.

- The previous version had some broken code, such as checking for the existence of id, although it is not set anywhere previously or passed to the function and creating an existingId variable for no purpose.  It also wrapped most of the function in a run loop, but I'm certain it's not necessary.
- The previous version would create a new record even if the child record has no primary key, which would auto-generate a new primary key and thus a new store key each time that same child record needed to be re-accessed.  It also did extra work fixing up the store by having to manipulate the id after creation.
- This version generates a re-usable id upfront for child records that don't have a primary key value.  This means that the id is unique to that child record and if the child record is unloaded and reloaded, even though it doesn't have a primary key, it will still get the same generated id and thus, get the same store key in the store, preventing the store from creating new objects and leaking the caches on the old child record.
- See previous unit tests checking that child records without primary keys keep or lose their id and storeKey properly when manipulated.

Fixes memory leak in the store when removing or replacing child records.

- The first time that you access a child record, the store updates four caches:  parentRecords (parentStoreKeys => [childStoreKeys]), childRecords (childStoreKeys => parentStoreKeys), records (SC.Record instances), dataHashes (SC.record backing attributes).
- Previously, if you set the child record to null or unloaded and reloaded the parent record or set the child record to a new child record and the child record doesn't have a primary key, the store would create duplicates on all these hashes, resulting in a memory leak.
- Now each time that you set the value of the child record on the parent, it clears the old child record caches in the store.
- See previous tests to prove the memory leak, by modifying the child record and checking the number of properties in the store's caches.

Fixes unit tests for child records that don't have primary keys.

- Child records should not need a primary key, since they are just part of the parent record and so they should not be modified to have a 'guid' property and should return null to childRecord.get('guid').
Adds tests proving that replacing child views or unloading reloading records with child views leaks objects in the store.

- Added unit test showing that the first selectable item becomes the default value when no value is set.  This prevents disabled items or separators from being default.
Removes a bunch of comments that don't mean anything.

Fixes mouse move, enter, exiting on SC.SegmentedView when a segment is disabled.

- previously, the disabled segment still received the active class when the mouse moved into it or over it
- added unit tests to show that the active class is properly applied

Fixes the styling for icons on SC.LabelView.

- the previous style caused the entire label to be position relative with middle vertical-align when an icon was included.  Those styles should only apply to the img.

Fixes theming of SC.SegmentedView.

- fixed the disabled style wasn't being applied to the view or its segments
- changed font size of regular size view from 11px to 12px which matches the font size of regular size button
- fixed the img positioning to be properly centred for the different size controls
Fixes typo in documentation of type property on SC.TextFieldView.

Fixes the application of defaultValues to the data hash in createRecord and also allows the provided hash to use the attribute name or the attribute key when there is a key.

- The previous implementation would assign 'null' data hash properties for every property in the record, now the data hash only includes record attributes
- The default value would be applied to the attribute name in the data hash, which didn't work if the attribute used a key
- Previously, if a record attribute had a key, then accidentally passing the attribute name instead of the attribute key would fail to work correctly.  Now it will accept the name and/or the key and only store the key in the data hash.
Adds tests to verify that the default value gets assigned to the store hash properly even when the record attribute has a 'key'.
Fixes the order of operations so that all unit tests pass and fixes missing dataHashDidChange call.
Prevents tests from failing because the defaultValue is applied to the store dataHash and thus should be the raw value.
Cleans whitespace.

Fixes issue applying defaultValue for properties not passed in the hash to SC.Store createRecord(), when the defaultValue is a function.

- Since the defaultValue may be a function and may rely on the `record` argument, we have to materialize the record before calculating default values.

Enables SC.GridView and SC.CollectionFastPath to work with sparse arrays.

Previously, SC.GridView would try to iterate through all items whenever its clippingFrame changed, triggering paging in of the entire sparse array unnecessarily.  Instead it's far better to just adjust those that are nowShowing and already paged in.  Also, SC.CollectionFastPath would return null if the item doesn't exist, so I made it operate like it does in SC.CollectionView to always return a view even is item is null.

SC.Color has the following capabilities:
- feature detection for rgba
- parser from rgb(a), hsl(a), hex, and argb values to a normalized rgb space
- converter from the normalized rgb space to rgb(a), hsl(a), hex, and argb notations
- hsl mutators to rotate the hue, saturate, or lighten a color

This CSS forces all panes to use H/W compositing layers, which has several unintended and problematic side effects. This closes issues #741 & #43

Added orderBy to the query so that the test remained consistent even if the previously "unordered" array's order changed.

Switch to ordering by storeKey if there is no order given.  This prevents a strange behaviour on Chrome that re-orders arrays when the length is greater than 10 and all the items compare as 0, which can be the case if the array is made of null guids like you would get from a RecordArray full of new un-committed records.

If you give Chrome an array of 10 or more items to sort where each item comparison is 0, Chrome will take the first item, swap it with the second item, take the new first item and swap it with the middle item (ie. length = 30, item 0 gets swapped with item 15).  This effects RecordArrays of new records without guids and this test shows it on Chrome by failing.

Updates to match new SC.browser usage, plus jsdoc

Bring standardization to the growing list of detected browsers, layout engines, devices and os's.
- Standardized set of properties on SC.browser:  device, name, version, engine, engineVersion, os, osVersion.  This will make it easier to match a specific browser (ex. Chrome), specific engine (ex. Webkit), a specific browser version (ex. Safari 5.0.5) or a specific engine version (ex. Webkit 533.16).
- Added constants for comparison: SC.BROWSER, SC.DEVICE, SC.ENGINE & SC.OS
- Better detection of browser version vs. layout engine version.
- Detecting blackberry browser/device/os.
- Detecting presto engine/version.
- Detecting gecko engine/version.
- Detecting android device/os.
- Several new user agents in unit tests.
- Added ISO 639-1 country code support and unit test: SC.browser.countryCode.
- Prevent bugs that exist when blindly transforming version Strings into Numbers for comparison.  For example, Version strings may have multiple sub-versions and may include letters like 'b' for beta. Use SC.browser.versionMajor(), SC.browser.versionMinor() or SC.browser.versionFloat() to correctly transform a version into a comparable Version.  (Not flawless, but much safer).
- Deprecated the multiple SC.browser properties, since there is no clear rule for what becomes a property (device vs. browser vs. engine vs. browser version vs. engine version) and it will be easy for future user agents to introduce bugs in any one of the properties since they are all calculated somewhat independently.

Fix for the issue described in f382e38b3b94 related to how TextFieldView handles a change to isTextArea. See extended commit message for potential breaking change.

As part of the bug fix, this change refactors responsibility for isTextArea completely into TextFieldView. Previously, it was awkwardly split by SC.FieldView and SC.TextFieldView. The change is fully compatible with the internal API, but if you have any application views that extend SC.FieldView and depend on the incomplete isTextArea logic in SC.FieldView, you will need to either extend from TextFieldView instead or implement your own support for isTextArea.

Failing test for case where isTextArea property of TextFieldView changes.

The issue is that when the property changes, the code necessarily updates the HTML but it attempts to attach events based on the HTML present in the DOM, resulting in a failure to wire up the change event properly. This case never arises if isTextArea is set statically at the time the TextFieldView is created. It arises if the property is changed after creation of the view, either manually or via a binding.

There is still a nasty bug on iPad related to touch events with SC.ScrollView that I'm determined to fix, but until then if we're going to throw an exception about it, we should at least spell correctly.

The touch deltas were always some crazy number, because they were subtracting the absolute start position from the relative current position.  This meant that the ScrollView would always grab any dragging touches, even if they haven't actually passed the tolerance amount.  This is particularly bad when you have nested ScrollViews, the inner ScrollView would never get a chance to scroll.

On iPad it is possible that the timer set in touchStart() will not have yet fired and that touchEnd() will come in in the same Run Loop as the one that started with the call to touchStart().  The bad thing that happens is that even though we cleared this.touch, occasionally if touchEnd() comes in right at the end of the Run Loop and then the timer expires and starts a new Run Loop to call beginTouchesInContent(), that this.touch will STILL exist here.  There's no explanation for it, and it's not 100% reproducible, but there is about a 40ms window where the firing timer and the end touch cause a crash.  What happens is that if we try to capture the touch that has already ended, assignTouch() in RootResponder will check touch.hasEnded and throw an exception.

Updated the observable mixin's initObservable method so that it is more robust when handling observer paths. Now compensates for when a given observer path has a dot index greater than 0 but the path doesn't start with "this". Instead if the first character is lower case then we assume the path is relative to the object, otherwise the path is considered relative to the window object. This was done since most people get confused using * and . when using the observes() function extension. This makes things easier (better developer ergonomics).

Fixed statechart framework so that a state's event handler is only invoked once per sent event to the statechart. A state's event handler was getting invoked more than once if a state has concurrent substates, which was causing unexpected problems.
Polymorphism requires datastore and added myself as Contributor

If a superclass was used to load a record first (ex.  toOne: {MyApp.Person}), then if a subclass later appeared with the same ID (ex. store.find(MyApp.Male, id), it would error out because the subclass would generate a new store key and as it passed the storeKey up to its superclass, the superclass would already have a different storeKey and throw an exception.  Plus store.recordTypesByStoreKey would forever be stuck on the superclass Record Type.

Instead of generating the key at the bottom and passing it up, I generate the key at the top and recursively pass it back.  That way if a subclass claims the ID later, it can get the current key from its superclass and claim the Record Type for store.recordTypesByStoreKey.

Make it possible for the handlebars helpers to generate tags other than Currently, the helpers "bind", "boundIf", "if", "with", and "unless" always generate a . This makes them unsuitable for rendering block-level content, because HTML does not technically allow block elements (like
) inside a . While browsers tend to gracefully handle such invalid HTML, it can cause subtle breakage. For example, jQueryUI makes assumptions that break if you put divs inside spans. This change allows an optional "tagName" parameter on the aforementioned helpers. So you can do: {{#if someProperty tagName="div"}}
Some Content...
{{/if}}

Deprecated SC.viewportOffset() for SC.offset().  The viewport offset is rarely what the developer wants to find (although it works for most SC apps), so SC.offset allows you to specify which relative element we want to get offset against: 'document', 'viewport' or 'parent'.  SC.offset() uses jQuery's offset() and position() functions, which should be faster and more accurate.

Plus unit tests.  Tested on: Safari 5, Firefox 3.6, iPad 3.2, iPad 4.2.1, iPhone 4.0.1, iPhone 4.2.1

Deprecated SC.viewportOffset() for SC.offset().  The viewport offset is rarely what the developer wants to find (although it works for most SC apps), so SC.offset allows you to specify which relative element we want to get offset against: 'document', 'viewport' or 'parent'.  SC.offset() uses jQuery's offset() and position() functions, which should be faster and more accurate.

Plus unit tests.  Tested on: Safari 5, Firefox 3.6, iPad 3.2, iPad 4.2.1, iPhone 4.0.1, iPhone 4.2.1
Cleaned up sc_requires and global var declaration

Fixed a bug with useStaticLayout, that created an infinite loop because static layout causes noisy frame change notifications when doing layer updates (ImageView's update is dependent on the frame, ie. infinite loop).

Also, the bug fix removes need to double check frame updates within canvas render delegate, so removed some code.

Also, pulled the inner frame math out of SC.ImageView into a SC.InnerFrame mixin.  Custom views will be able to mix it in and then align and scale an inner element.  For example, this will be useful for custom list items that wish to best fit an img element without needing to rewrite the math themselves.

Finally, fixed some inaccurate unit tests and added tests for static layout with img and canvas elements.

The segment render delegate.

This is a stable work-in-progress rewrite of SC.SegmentedView.  In this version, support for render delegates.  Previously, there was a lot of logic in the renderer to maintain the individual segments.  I attempted to move that logic out by replacing displayItems with render delegate dataSources, but since so much of SC.View is required, I made the segments into childViews.  This simplifies the render delegates significantly.

I've tested this change and it achieves its goal for me at least!

Observable: Make logged changes fully inspectable on the console

By passing a second argument to console.log, we allow users to
interactively inspect the new value on the console, which is
particularly useful for simple structures (such as frames and layouts)
which do not normally print in a useful fashion.

I don't know about the portability implications of this patch.

RecordAttribute: Allow null dates

This fixes the following error message when a Date field is left
unspecified:

  TypeError: Cannot call method 'toString' of null

We do this by passing nulls straight through the conversion function.

Leaves the view with only a default background color, which is usually something the developer overrides. I removed the border on account that I never used borders in my use of ToolbarView, and I was tired of redundant overriding via custom CSS. I hope this is something other developers find useful.

Fixed a bug in the store that was triggering an erroneous call to the data source.

If the record was destroyed while in the READY_NEW state, it would transition
to the DESTROYED_CLEAN state.  However, in commitRecords(), DESTROYED_CLEAN
records were being added to the array of dirty records that were sent to the
data source for deletion.

This commit fixes that.

Implemented error storage/retrieval mechanism on the store.

Errors passed into the store via the error callbacks (dataSourceDidError()
and dataSourceDidErrorQuery()) are now written to internal arrays
(recordErrors and queryErrors, respectively).  These errors can then be
retrieved via calls to readError() and readQueryError().  Also modified the
errorObject computed properties on SC.Record and SC.RecordArray to invoke
these functions.  This way, when a record or record array transitions to the
error state, a simple get('errorObject') call will return the relevant
SC.Error object for inspection.

The readError() and readQueryError() functions on SC.NestedStore are simply
delegated to the parent store.

Fix bugs when finding next/previous selectable items in SC.CollectionView.

Add context and tests for SC.CollectionView selection delegate.

  * Should use isSelectable to determine selectability in the absence of a delegate
  * Should query the delegate for selectability
  * Should select the next selectable item
  * Should select the previous selectable item
  * Should retain selection when no previous item is selectable
  * Should retain selection when no further item is selectable

Add collection view selection methods to SC.CollectionViewDelegate:

  * collectionViewShouldSelectItem

Slighly faster split divider

View helper :spit_view inserts :split_divider_view automatically.

* Use :splitter => :thin to get a 0-pixel splitter (1 pixel thickness),
  or :splitter => :thick to get a 9-pixel splitter. Defaults to 5-pixel splitter.

Improved default CSS support for split views, and themed support. Ability to set thickness of splitter by using :splitter => :thin or :thick (defaults to :default) on the split_view helper. A thin splitter is zero-width (or 1 pixel), default is 5 pixels wide, thick is 9 pixels wide, last two inclusive 1px borders (following OSX HI Guidelines). Added :top, :bottom, :right, :left as common css keys as absolute positioning is key to SC.
Added image to sprite image for vertical split-divider-view, added css style
make sc-split-divider-view direct descendant of horizontal resp vertical sc-split-view (so that you can have e.g. a vertical split view within a horizontal one)
Change cursor style of split divider view when a boundary is hit.

Added :collapse_at_thickness property for child views of split views. When the divider is dragged beyond
the point where the thickness of a child view would become less than the value of this property, then the child view will collapse. Added more docs to split_view.
Re-implementation of SC.SplitView and SC.SplitDividerView. See tickets #128 and #129.

Refactored server.js. REST Server is now in it's own class.

Improved REST. The default for SC.Server is now to behave RESTfully. The backend can control the API that is exposed to the client by sending refreshURL, updateURL and/or destroyURL in responses to SC requests.
RESTful server.js
commitRecords sends _method=put and destroyRecords sends _method=delete to accommodate REST aware servers
